chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: This book is out to rectify injustices done from impure speech; particularly in the usage of the categories of non-Jews within Jewish Law: the Torah. This book will help to end antisemitism by re-humanizing the non-Jew within the Torah through the lens of proper terms used for non-Jews and their respective laws. There is a vicious cycle of de-humanization between the Jew and non-Jew that can be stopped by using pure speech and logical application of that speech to proper definitions within Torah. Torah has never been the problem. Rather, misunderstandings of different types of non-Jews is the main problem in this regard. Specifically, this book is about subsets of non-Jews, their critical definitions, and Torah law pertaining to their respective non-Jew subsets. These subsets are either entirely mutually exclusive, or have only some mutual exclusivity in respect to their properties. For instance, the set of all humans have chromosomes, but not all humans keep kosher; so the subsets are defined in respect to the properties wrote about in this book. This book is about specific subsets of non-Jews and their respective properties. These subsets or categories, are called gedarim in Hebrew.

Once the reader sees the different gedarim of non-Jews within Torah using their proper Hebrew nouns as described in this book, the reader will be able to see the improper usage of terms about the different non-Jews and how such terms lead to misunderstanding and misapplication of Torah law, foundational misquotes for antisemitism, etc. An example, is a translation of a major redactor of Jewish Law known as the R"AMBAM which says in his Mishneh Torah that a non-Jew who studies the Torah is obligated to die. Such a translation that depicts all non-Jews not only sounds horrible, it's actually wrong. In reality, the verse in the original Hebrew is only in relation to wicked non-Jews, who for the most part in our western culture today, don't exist. Unfortunately, this is the common translation of such verses of Torah law pertaining to non-Jews. Such translations and traditions about the non-Jew promulgate within the unlearned Jewish community and eventually end up in the non-Jewish community.

Gedarim have certain properties associated with them. For instance, let's look at the word goy. The geder for goy has a legal status such that a goy that gives tzedakah/charity to bnei Yisrael/child of Israel(colloquially: a Jew): bnei Yisrael cannot benefit from that tzedakah and the tzedakah must be given instead to the goy poor. However, when a ben Noach/child of Noah, which is under a different geder gives charity to bnei Yisrael, the poor of bnei Yisrael can use that tzedakah. Even more so, Yisrael has a mitzvah/commandment to sustain the life of a ben Noach in trouble, while bnei Yisrael have no such mitzvah for the goy. Even contrary, bnei Yisrael are obligated to not save a goy from death. So then, one must ask: What is a goy? What is a ben Noach? Why are they treated differently?

Many will tell you that the goy and the ben Noach are the same thing: that they're all gentiles or non-Jews. However, as one can see, they're not. There is some mutual exclusivity, as we just read, between the goy and the ben Noach who gives tzedakah. These different categories of non-Jews will be explained in this book. This book will properly show some correct definitions and differences of these gedarim of non-Jews, which will expose many horrible translations or misunderstandings about quotes of Torah taken out of context to wrongfully justify de-humanization or hatred of the Jew and non-Jew. This book will help break that vicious cycle by bringing back purity of language and help bring peace.
"For then I will restore to the peoples a pure language, That they all may call on haShem, To serve Him with one accord." - Zephaniah 3:9 The R"AMBAM in his Mishneh Torah, Hilchot Melachim 10:10, shows a good example of two different gedarim.
"A ben Noach that wants to do a mitzvah/commandment from the other mitzvot of the Torah(beyond the seven of bnei Noach) in order to receive reward, [Yisrael] does not keep him from doing it properly. And if he brings a burnt offering, we receive it. If he gives tzedakah, we receive it from him and it appears to me that it is given to the poor of Yisrael. He receives his sustenance from Yisrael and it is a mitzvah to sustain his life. However, the goy that gives tzedakah, we receive it and give it to the poor goyim" - R"AMBAM, Hilchot Melachim 10:10 Even though both goy and ben Noach are in the set of non-Jews, they are their own respective subset with their own respective properties and laws. These sets or categories are called gedarim and it is these sets and their respective properties is mostly what this book is about.
